Bottle: brown pour with medium-sized beige head. Aroma is a yeasty caramel. Flavor is belgian yeast with a slight funk, caramel, apple cider, toasted bread and ends with a growing alcohol warmth. Palate is mostly sweet with a mild spiciness and a slight carbonation and alcohol tingle. This was a decent beer but was lacking in spice and carbonation.

Reminds me of a doppelbock, and a pretty decent one.  Nose is a bit sour, with plums, caramel.  Palate is granny smith apples, caramel, yeastiness.  Sweet and sour intermingle in a nice harmony.  Syrupy yet not sticky sweet palate and mouthfeel.  Appearance is a reddish tan brown, unusual and nice.  Nice hazy small layer of  swirly foam stays on top.  Spotty lacing.  From Nathaniels.
deep amber little foam. heavy sugary aroma, full of belgian candy sugar and yeasty notes. yaste is sweet sugary, malty notes. belvian yeazt nites and dried fruits / dates.

750 ml bottle. Pours a clear dark red/brown with light head. Aromas of toast, spice, roasted malt, and brown sugar. Flavors of roasted malts, Belgian yeast (very nice), light caramel, raisins, and a bit of spice. Excellent Belgian tribute.

Pours the color of apple cider with a fluffy white head. Aroma is heavy with apples and a little vanilla. Taste is apples, yeasty spiciness, and finishing with some caramel and vanilla. Lively palate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Smelling of spices, raisins, vinegar and yeast.Appearance: A foggy amber colored beer. A low off-white head with small lacing and good curtains.Taste: Tasting sweet fruits, spices, clove and old french cider.Palate: High carbonation, foamy bubbles, a soft texture. A good body with a slight dry finish.Overall: A really good ale IMHO, I liked the acidity and cider character.Note: Bottle 650 ml at a De Klomp tasting. Reviewed 2012-12-29.

Bottle, shared with Bergen Beer Geek Tasting Crew on Christmas Tasting 2012. Another biggie poppin! :-) Deep light coppery body, short-lasting big foamy beige head. Nose is banana, bready notes, candy sugars, hints of wood and caramel. Taste is sweet caramelly banana notes, hints of raisins, herbs, grass and nuts. Some figs in the aftertaste. Nice enough. Full body, medium carbonation. A good BSA, but far from the best AleSmith has to offer.
Bottle at Brewdog Camden, pours a ruby red. Lively carbonation. Aroma of berries, cherries, and a little caramel & chocolate malt. Very moreish, just as good as some of the top belgians

from Erzbierschof - cloudy dark amber-red beer with a little foam left; estery aroma with notes of pear and apples; slightly spicy; pretty sweet and with some acidic tartness; lively and tasty, full-bodied; highly carbonated; long fizzy fruity and estery finish with notes of marzipan, alcohol and spices

Thanks Teo for sharing this one. Pours amber-red, with a tall and lasting off-white head. Delivers to the nose a complex aroma, yeasty and sweet, with something that recalls white wine. Taste is spiced, with some caramel, dried fruits, a little of citrus well balances the sweetness. Full bodied, and fizzy carbonation, maybe too much for me. Meditation beer, very enjoyable shared with a good friend.

Solid Belgian-style brew. Pours burgundy/brown with a bubbly-ass head. Smell toffee, raisin, roastiness and taste the same with a little more fruitiness and other goodness from the yeast plus some nice spice. Finishes pretty boozy, sticky, and sugary.

Bottle. Pours unclear red-amber with a lasting foamy beige head. Aroma is raisin, toffee, orange, dried fruits, caramel notes, apples, nail polish, citrus peel. Taste is heavy sweet like candy. Full body, quite carbonated, texture is creamy and sticky. The finish is long, boozy, spicy and sweet. Technically a well made brew, but I really didnt enjoy it because its so boozy and sweet.

Bottle from Brewdog. Pours dark brown with a big long lasting white creamy head. Aroma is complex, vinous with raisins, dark fruits and mild caramel. Taste is as good as expected from the aroma, complex malty vinous sweetness, light vanilla and oak. Full bodied, light alcohol lurking underneath. Very good beer. Fruity with a twist at the end.

Like Belgian beers Grand cru. Pours hazy brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, caramel, cinnamon and some apple. Flavour is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a murky reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is of toasted malt, nutty notes, raisins, prunes and sweeter dark fruits, doughy breadiness, dark Belgian candied sugar, toffee and caramel, subtle spice ester from the yeast, red grape and red apple. The flavor follows the nose with lots of nice fruit esters (reminds me of the ester in Westmalle), again raisins, prunes, sweeter dark fruits, red grape, red apple, but also some doughy breadiness, toasted malt, nuts, toffee, caramel, spice and Belgian candied sugar. The body is medium with a dry and silky mouth feel. Overall a pretty tasty Belgian Strong Dark Ale.

750 mL bottle. Dark copper with a medium, fluffy, head. Big caramel and toasted notes, with coriander and cardamon spiciness and mild yeasty ester notes of apples and lemons. Very sweet up front, with a mild sour and bitter finish. Heavy body, with a sticky, grainy, syrupy, and sticky mouthfeel. Overall, this is a big, malty beer, with obvious yeast notes. Not as complex as I would like, but a good beer nonetheless.

Aroma of vanilla with a hint of tart/vinegar. Clear brown/amber with little head and no lacing to speak of. Taste is vanilla, malt, raisins, maybe some tropical notes from the belgian yeast. Palate is thin, high alcohol. Great beer, very unique.

Big bottle won in a fantasy baseball league. Thanks!Underwelming. Deep brown in color with perhaps a bit of red tone also. Scant head formation. Aroma is richly malty but with undertones of tin. Flavor is decently malted, caramel and a bit chocolatey. Somewhat yeasty and peppery. Solid but not stellar.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Julios Liquors purchased in 2010.  It pours a deep, ruddy color with a slight, light tan head.  The nose has heavy dough notes, but is fairly expressionless outside of that.  The flavor on the other hand is very complex with lots of sherry and port like notes.  Nice dried fruit, light vanilla notes, and a touch of paper too.  Medium bodied with a lasting finish.  While not oxidized out this one is seems to be just over the peak of the hill.  Still, I loved the complexity and would happily get another one.

750 ml Bottle. Pours a deep amber/burgundy color with a cap of beige foam and bubbles. Aroma has notes of brown sugar, vanilla and dark fruit in addition to some toffee and alcohol around the edges. The taste opens up with lots of candi sugar, caramel and Belgian yeast flavors along with some toasted malt, raisin and black cherry. Toward the end theres a bit of cocoa, plum and woody alcohol in the background. The body is silky smooth and creamy with heavy carbonation and a dry, malty finish. Overall, a rich malt bomb with just enough of a Belgian influence to hold all the massive flavors together.

(From notes 7 Nov, 2012) Bottle. Head settles fast. Clear, dark amber pour. Aroma somehow reminds me of Gouden Carolus Classic. Strange association, but nice. Flavor has hints of banana, alcohol. Mouthfeel is creamy. Finish is dry, alcohol bitter. Overall hard to say, other than its okay. I am surprised by the very high score on RB.

AROMA: dough, vanilla, dark fruits, ends in chocolate dryness
APPEARANCE: red, brown, clear, minimal head, 
TASTE: medium bitterness, 
PALATE: medium body, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, 
OVERALL: starts as a strong beer, moves to a warming summer wine, alcohol well-hidden, very good finish in a chocolaty-dryness.

Pours ruby amber brown in color with a big creamy beige. The aroma brings sweet aged malts and a bit of liqueury booze. The flavor tastes more like a barleywine, bringing sweet maltiness going throughout the taste and settling on the palate.
Bottle shared with Marus. 2006 vintage. Color looks similar to a barely wine. Taste is creamy with Carmel taste. Taste is kinda smooth.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2013 Pours dark reddish brown with large head that recedes quickly. Cery effervescent. Aroma of mostly fruit and yeast. A hint of spice. Flavor is heavy on prunes and fig, with a bit of toffee. Mouthfeel is lighter than I expected. A good bite on the way down to balance out the sweet fruit. A lot going on here. Solid brew. Would like to have one of these age now that Ive tried it fresh.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fruity, yeasty aromas with some sweet malt aromas. Sweet malts and finger nail polish flavors. Overall a very good Belgian style.

Bottle at home from brewdog online.
Pours transparent amber brown with a slight creamm head. Belgian yeast esters on the nose, fairly sweet, but with a dryness too, caramel, stewed pairs. Full bodied but easy drinking.
Sample @ SBWF 12. Clear colour with a medium tan head. Aroma of fruit, caramel, malt. Flavour of yeasty fruit with some bitterness.

Bottle bought at Kihoskh, shared with esp0r, edvard and simonsen september 29th 2012. Deep red brown colored body, thick offwhite head. Malty aroma with red fruits, caramel and belgian yeast. Sweet malt taste with candy sugar, berries, vanilla and orange. Sweet peppery finish.

Bottle from 2007.
Pours a dark ruby brown with a smallish bubbly off white head that dissipates rather quickly. Smells of caramel and brown sugar with a fair bit of melanoid, spice, peeper, and a touch of alcohol round out the nose quite well. The flavor is sweet up front with brown sugar and caramel. Melanoid, prunes and plums come in with a bit of alcohol and licorice midway through. Long lingering sweet burnt sugar lingers long after every sip. Medium to thick body with a light level of carbonation and a sweet almost syrupy mouthfeel. Nice brew, I really enjoyed it. I would have liked a touch more carbonation, but I can live with it as is.

Bottle shared by daje at the daje & esp0r hits #1000 rates sessions
Pours copper hazy with a big beige head. Smells of belgian yeast esters, caramel, clove and malts. Taste is medium to heavy sweet, full of caramel and spices, some dark and dried fruits as well. Medium bitter, quite fruity. A very nice belgian; nice complex aromas and flavors blended harmonic.
On draft at alesmith. Pours cola brown with a tan head. Banana lacquer aroma. Toffee and banana bread. Soft carbonation. Slightly bitter finish.

A reddish coppery beer with a medium and blond head. Aroma is complex, dry spices, bun and yeast, fruits also some dark fruits and dates. Taste is mildly fruitfull, yeast, some marsmallows, spices, aftertaste is slightly musty. Sweetness is mild and balanced. Medium bodied, quite light to drink. Quite nice and complex beer but sophistication that can be found from the best belgian ale is missing.
Drukket på hytta til dag med entusiaster. Rødfarget øl som skummer mye. Smak med mye fruktihet med innslag av gress og humle

750 ml bottle - pours red amber with steady head. Aroma is a bit off - a bit oxydised (my guess is due to transport) but still lots of malt, caramel, honey and spices. Full body with sweet and full richness. Clear caramel notes. I miss a bit a balance, but a quite OK beer.

12oz pour at Baileys Taproom. Beautiful dark pour, lively head. Thing that stands out for me is the yeast zip on this one... sourness, which I love. Nicely complex and entirely enjoyable. Favorite Ale Smith beer?

Deep reddish brown. Lots of sweet malt on the nose, molasses and grape. Taste is molasses, almond, alcohol. Strong brew, interesting flavors, but alcohol is a little too assertive and ruins the balance.
Bottle 3 Beer tasting club - Brown colour with no murkiness a beige head. Sweet malts quite bitter which I like.

750ml bottle. Clear brown, red glowing colour with average, micropore, beige head. Very fruity aroma has notes of red and blue berries, a minimal dry leather touch of fruit parings, decent tartness. Taste is decently sweet fruity, notes of red and blue berries, subtle carbonation. Almost light in character for its high abv.

Bottle.  Pours reddish-brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, caramel malts, yeast, light spices and a hint of alcohol.  Flavors of dark fruits, mild yeast, moderate hop bitterness and light spice.  Fruit, yeast and alcohol on the finish.
Spicy Belgian character, peppery. Huge Belgian flavors kicking around-too much for me overall.

pours a clear brown with a red tint, a medium size tan head, and some lacing.

smell is of caramel, some sweetness, pear, and berry.

taste is smooth, fruit, a little sweet, grapes, berries, a touch of caramel, and a few malts.  ends clean.

Bottle at ginger man NYC. Dark amber appearance. 2 finger head that fades very fast. Scent has Tons of dark fruits figs and raisins. Some burnt sugar aspects. Taste is very interesting. Very dry and very intense lightly sweetened fruits. Overwhelming grape skins and figs. Heavy body. Pretty interesting.
Gedronken bij joes, bruin van kleur, helder. Ruikt zoet, klein beetje fruitig bla bla. Smaakt bla bla. Veel koolzuur.

Bottle, courtesy of Kermis. Clear amber colour, of-white head. Floral hoppy aroma with sweet maltiness and caramel. Taste has a lot sweet fruit flavours and has some hoppy influences. This was a really nice drink!

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours hazy brown with a tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, caramel, cinnamon and some apple.  Flavour is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

13/VIII/2012 75cl bottle from De Hopduvel (Gent) @ Klaas place - BB: n/a (2012-925) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Clear ruby red to copper  beer, small off-white to yellowish head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: bit sweet, malty, ripe fruits, bit floral, sour red berries, caramel. MF: lively carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty sourish, overripe fruit, sweet, quite alcoholic, bit lemony. Aftertaste: ripe fruits, little bitter, red berries, overripe fruits, bit funky, earthy. Not exactly overwhelmed by this one. 99? cmon... at least a third of what we put out here in Belgium is better than this...

A clear light brown colored beer, with a small light beige head. The aroma of fruits, a little cherry, flowery, with some sweet malts. The taste of sweet fruits, a little cherry, malty. Notes of vanilla ans a little alcohol. The aftertaste is sweet with bitter notes.

75cl bottle. Pours hazy amber, with a gentle stream of bubbles and a generous head. Nose of ginger bread and apple. The taste has more baked apple maybe cinnamon. Theres toffee apple on the end. The palate is medium to full bodied with a huge tangy middle and a nice long tart finish. Overall, delicious!
Taken from old notes. Nose of sour fruits and caramel. Taste is sweet malts and yeast. Finish is dry with a lingering aftertaste. Can taste the alcohol. Nice sipper.

750 ml bottle (from 06 I think).  I cant believe that I havent rated this yet although Ive enjoyed it many times.  Pours a clear reddish brown color with a medium sized beige head that doesnt last long.  The aroma has a nice Belgian yeast character, chocolate, vanilla, raisins and other dark fruits.  The flavor is much of the same, but adds some caramel and toasted bread.  There is a nice tangy bite at the beginning that moves into a smooth tasty finish.  This is a very solid beer that I am glad to have pretty regular access to.

75cl bottle thanks to Joes. Lightly unclear dark orange to red color, medium to full sized dense off-white head. Smell malts, some sourness and yeast. Taste malts, slightly yeasty, some alcohol, lightly sweet. Full, a bit fizzy carbonation, medium body.

Bottle thx to joes. Hazy orange to copper, big white head. Smells malts, grains, iron, water. Tastes very sweet, caramel, malts, grains.. Not my favorite beer. Lots of carbo (way to much), medium body.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle into a brandy snifter. Pours a translucent amber with a thick, creamy froth of white foam that has really nice retention. The aroma is fairly strong estery notes with a sweet Belgian candi sugar flair to it. Taste is smooth esters with a heavier influence of clove than anything else. My only complaint about this beer is its a little thin. It didnt feel quite right. Regardless, the beer is quite nice.

Draught at the brewery. Almost clear, brown liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of banana, caramel, biscuit, bubblegum and sweet cereal. Taste is light to medium sweet and medium bitter with notes of banana and caramel. Full bodied with medium carbonation.

A fantastic beer - sour to me, overall complex and compelling.  I am listening to Bachs second sonata for violin alone and it fits very well - for me it is due to the implied polyphony throughout - even in the fugue there are implied lines and this beer flows with the music, and it with it.  Great experience.

On bottle at Olympen, Oslo.
Dark reddish color, ok foam ( typical Belgian).

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very sweat. Strong smells of banana bread for me. Still a good dark Belgian style. 

On tap at the brewery.
Bottle: pours cloudy/hazy reddish brown, aroma is sweet, sour, some dark fruit, taste is caramel, dark fruit, a slight tartness, sweetness lingers in the finish.  Nice.

1999 vintage shared by Brad at my tasting on May 29, 2010. Thanks!

This beer appears a thin, chestnut brown hue with very minimal head and no lace. Being over a decade old, this is a typical result. Aromas consist of Belgian yeast strains, white wine, apples. The beer tastes pretty good overall. The feel is slightly thin. There is a slight burn in the finish, though the 10% abv is disguised fairly well in the taste. Alesmith Grand Cru tastes like Belgian apple juice. Good stuff.

750 ml bottle from Ludlow Wines, purchased a few years ago. 2009 probably, 2010 at the latest. Pours a cloudy amber color with a small off-white ring for a head. Aroma of dark and dried fruits, brown sugar, caramel, leather, and cookies. Flavor of dark fruits, caramel, brown sugar, graham crackers, apples, sweet bread, and a little cardboard. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, bready mouthefel and moderate carbonation. Id be interested to try other vintages of this to see how it does fresher and older.
A very strong belgian-styled ale form an american brewer. I thought I was drinking something from Belgium.
Bottle pours a hazy orange with a thick off white head. Scent is malt, spice and pepper. Taste is somewhat sweet but not too much. Fruity, yeasty and spices etc.
Hazy dark orange with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 180612
Amber with a cream head.  Nose is dried fruits, yeast, spices, apples.  Smooth palate, dried fruits, peaches, apples, heavy yeast.

Pours a coke color with medium carbonation. Smells of malt and raisin. Taste is similar with a prominent but not bad licorice flavor. I prefer a heavier palate. This one is lighter on body than I like. Good beee though.

Bottle. Pours hazy orangy amber with a medium sized off-white head. Good lacing. Nose of caramel, floral hops and yeast notes. Sweet flavor with slightly toasted malt, vanilla, dried fruit and caramel. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Ends up more dry with an alcohol touch. A world class beer.

750ml bottle. Pours murky brownish red with a big frothy khaki head that has some of the best head retention Ive seen, lasting over an hour as I sipped it. Aroma of spicy Belgian yeast esters, toffee, alcohol and dried fruit. Flavor is fruity/spicy yeast, lightly sweet caramel and a mild alcohol warming. Medium body with lively carbonation that explodes in your mouth. Served slightly chilled, this got a lot nicer as it warmed to room temperature and some of the carbonation subsided. Great beer.

Pours a deep golden amber, with a frothy off-white head. Sweet aroma of apples, grapes, citrus fruits, cherries, and bread. Crisp, yet potent on the palate with a subtle aftertaste of fermenting fruits. Definitely taste the alcohol alongside the fruity taste.

Pours brownish red with no head or lacing.  Aroma is plum, orange peel, alcohol, and currants.  taste is plum, clove, grape and currants.  finish is boozy and sweet.  a lovely beer that I can imagine aging well.

Bottled:Dark orangey amber colour. Large head. Sweet and malty caramel aroma with notes of oranges. Sweet, thick and oily mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet caramel, cherries and alcohol. Harsh finish. Just a little bit too sweet and boozy for me.

Bottle. dark red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, berries, caramel. Flavour is is sweet and sour, roasted malt, licorice, caramel, berries, alcohol, dried fruits. Full body. Very nice beer.

Pours cloudy orangish brown with a great tan head. Head is smooth like well steamed latte milk with good retention. Yeast, barnyard funk and dark sugar on the nose. Taste is rich and smooth, with rich caramel, candy, yeast, hint of vanilla and a little citrus-like tartness. Med carbonation. Full bodied. After taste is rich sweet with some dry hops and alcohol. Interesting ale, a little on the sweet side, but very good.

Coppery amber in color with a huge foamy tannish head. Wine-like, with a tartness and a sour sweetness tempered with caramel like malt flavors. Fizzy and carbonated with a lot of deep fruit, the alcohol is definitely there.

Pour clear red/dark orange, with a huge creamy white head. Aroma of plums, prunes, caramel, Belgian yeasty funkiness. Also some brown sugar, bread, and perhaps some unripe cherries/berries, to ad some sourness

Pour clear red/dark orange, with a huge creamy white head.
Aroma of plums, prunes, caramel, Belgian yeasty funkiness. Also some brown sugar, bread, and perhaps some unripe cherries/berries, to ad some sourness. 
Taste is sweet, with some sour notes.
Medium body, with plenty of fizzy carbonation. Rather dry finish on this one.

Thanks to Deuane for bringing this 06 bottle to Stakems Fish Fry.

A - Pours murky brown with a half finger tall off-white head leaving small trails of lace down some of the glass.

S - Smells of sweet caramel malt, brown sugar, toffee, dark fruits, figs, some cherries and a bit of spicy/sweet belgian yeast. The booze is all but gone from the nose.

T - Starts off with a bunch of sweetness - mostly made up of toffee, brown sugar and caramel malt - slowly giving way to hints of dark fruits, cherries, vanilla and some spicy yeast. Only a tiny bit of booze creeps as it warms up, warming the end of each sip. Finish has some sweetness, lingering on the pallet long after consumption.

M - Big body with a creamy sweet feel and moderate carbonation. The flavors are fairly sweet throughout with very little booze detectable.

O - I liked this one. The flavors worked well and it was surprisingly easy to drink. It appears to be at its peak now, maybe beginning to slide a little bit.
Bomber from Andy--what a treat! pours a dark ruby. generally sweet, lots of dark fruit to it, cherry and plum, and a nice alcohol warming at the end. Good beer.

750ml bottle, shared with friends. Thin off-white head, fading to minimal. Clear red color. Dry texture. Lighter, smoother carbonation. Nice, sweet belgian-candy taste. Nice, rich dark fruit aroma. Some [complex lemony] notes. Friends liked this better than the AleSmith Wee Heavy (which I shared just before this bottle).
Bottle. Amber. Cherries and other misc dark fruits, roasted malts, some chocolate, caramel, warm alcohol, candy, spices. Complex. Smooth, medium body.

On tap it has a dark amber color in the glass with a large head. It has dark fruits and roasted malt aroma. Flavor is big but smooth. It has a balance of fruit like cherries and rasberries. There is a thick caramel taste with a finish of alcohol. Good beer.

Pours a beautiful dark amber with a fairly big white-yellowish head. Very thick foam. Aroma is belgian yeast, caramel, a hint of vanilla and some fresh herbal tones. Taste is initially a touch sour before going into a sweeter territory fueled by caramel malt, toffee and warming alcohol. Body is rich, full and creamy with moderate carbonation to balance it up. Finish is long and sweet with the alcohol very present. A great beer and probably my favorite carrying the grand cru designation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours amber with low head
aromas of belgian yeast, orange peel, peach, honey
palate is creamy and at the same time quite frizzy. sweet start with sour ending. the ending is a bit too abrupt
taste has some oakyness together with the sweetness.
This is a very fine tuned, smooth beer but what lowers the rate is the slight watery ending

[Bottle, thanks for sharing, Guerde!] Pours reddish brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is very nice--loads of dark fruits, along with a big dose of chocolate, black cherry and red grapes especially shine through as it warms. Taste is just a little hot, but otherwise a lot of nice dark fruits again, chocolate, notes of honey, and underlying toasted malt. Medium mouthfeel, smooth, average length finish. Overall, a really, really nice beer. Thanks again, Andy!

Sweetish licorice taste with some dried fruits, caramel, candybar, spices. Sort of mixture between a Dubbel, a Quadrupel and a winterbeer. Bit low on body.
UPDATED: AUG 28, 2012 Bottle @ home. Aroma is big liquorice, red fruit, caramel malt, some spices. Flavour is caramel, liquorice, red fruits, some spice. Expected a bit more.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2012 Dark ruby, light tan head. Spiced aroma, nutty, dry yeast. Belgian aroma. Taste is sharp from alcohol, bit boring otherwise. Not expressive enough. Warming aftertaste. Not as good as hoped. Too little sweetness. Some (At the De Molen tasting) 
Re-rated: Fresh bottle this time, so it reveals more hops. Still the taste disappoints.

Sample glass at de molen beer tasting.
Thin white head.  Ruby clear pour.  Smooth aftertaste.

Bottle at monthly tasting session @ De Molen, hosted by dEnk. Hazy reddish amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is somewhat alcoholic, fruity, raisins and caramel. Flavor is fruity, somewhat sweet, alcoholic, warming and well balanced. A bit strong.

750ml bottle.
Pours a deep mahogany, haze, with a beige head.
Spicy, fruity aroma, caramel malt, candied sugar, spicy yeast notes, walnuts.
Off dry, full bodied, medium bitterness, balanced CO2.
Fruity, spicy, yeasty taste, candied sugar, dried fruits, figs, earth, 
(2012-03-01)

Aroma- Sweet dark fruits, some vanilla, burnt sugars
Appearance- Clear toasted brown with a big fluffy tan head that lasts with nice drippy lacing.
Flavor- Starts of tangy, then the creamy caramel and vanilla start in. 
Very complex with lots going on with this beer.

A clear amber beer with no lace.  Strong aromas of caramel, vanilla, banana, apple and pear.  Starts sweet roasted malty and but dry and Belgian spiced. Plenty of yeast..  Exhibits more caramelized flavors fruit flavors.  Not much bitterness.  Feels slick but with prickly carbonation.  It warms you up as you drink it.  A really nice and harmonious Belgian.  A go to for me for bringing to dinner parties.

Pours a dark brownish red color with a huge long lasting pillowy tan head. Aroma is nothing but belgian yeast and caramel malts. Taste is spicy belgian with nice malts, bt there is a weird metallic. Character I dont like. Not too bad besides the metallic taste.

750 ml. bottle.  Pours brown with a nice biege head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, and yeast.  Taste is sweet malt, brown sugar, molasses, and dark fruit.  Warming.  For me a bit too sweet.  Very nice though.

Bottle. Pours a clear reddish brown with a large off white head. Good lacing. Aroma is Belgian yeast, vanilla, and a slight floral hoppiness. Taste is much the same, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, hops, vanilla. Mouthfeel is light with good carbonation. Finishes warm. I will definitely be having this again.

Shared with Holy.   Aroma of cloves and caramel.  Poured too soon after traveling so cloudy, instead of clear.   Blend of caramel and citrus with a bread background.  Good, but it may be better if kept away from airplanes.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with quiznoaz - thank you! Well, the description set me straight! I had to taste the Grand Cru, to be able to appreciate the Grand Cru. Well enough - I really didnt appreciate it before I opened it, so the caption was DEAD ON! Additionally, my Grand Cru was a little cloudy - a huge fail on my part to serve it Crystal clear... I have no business to rate this any further. Dont judge me.

Bottle at home, out of my Maudite glass. Pours clear bronze, with a hint of brown. One and a half finger thick off-white head; ropey lacing. Nose is very funky, like Limburger cheese, is this intentional? Lots of cherry, and yeast notes, but overall a quite simple, if unique nose. Flavours of cherry, chocolate, brandy, red licorice. Okay, nothing real special...
Pours copper with an off white head. Aroma of malt, spicy fruits.  Flavor is sweet and fruity and acidic.

Poured into a snifter. 2010 vintage. I reviewed a fresh bottle (which was lost in one of BAs "lost review" moments) and didnt care for it much. Well see if this is any better with some time on it.

3.0 A: Opaque medium brown color. Two fingers of fizzy beige head. Retention is below average and no lacing is left.

3.0 S: Brown sugar, caramel, and a rum soaked raisin type booziness. Fig and prune fruitiness. Some toastiness in there as well. Peppery spiciness. Light bready maltiness. The flavor profile looks better on paper than how it actually smells. The aromas dont balance each other out that well. Still, not bad.

2.5 T: This has mellowed to the point of being boring. Brown sugar and caramel are the strongest flavors. Almost tart fruitiness featuring dates, figs, and raisins. Light peppery spiciness. Booze is in check though.

2.5 M: Medium body. Carbonation level is right, but its a "passive" carbonation as opposed to the spritzy Belgain yeast carbonation that I like. Seems almost oily. Smooth though.

2.5 D: Didnt care for it fresh and I care for it even less with some age. Its not undrinkable, but its boring with a subpar mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-27-2011 05:11:45

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep brown but transparent with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, caramel and light chocolate, and vanilla, plus floral hops.  Flavor about the same, with a lot of yeast, malts, and sweetness.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good beer.
Bottle thanks to DaSilky. Pours caramel brown with light brown head. Nose and taste of caramel, vanilla, mixed fruits, Belgian yeast, gummy bears and light chocolate. Medium body.

Bottle.Pours copper with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, red fruits, caramel, spices, yeast and vanilla. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some red berries,warming, caramel and malt.Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle, 75cl. A big, off-white to light beige head sits on top of an unclear, reddish dark amber body. The aroma has dried fruits, caramel notes, some beef stock, a touch of roasted malts and alcohol, and some faint sourish touch. The flavor isnt much badder, balancing sweetness, bitterness and sourness in a very nice way. Some roasted malts, a solid dose of fruityness and sweetness, some sour hints in the far back, as well as sugars and berries. Full-bodied, dry and sweet, with a  carbonation level that suits it well. Overall, certainly a beauty, which isnt unusual for an AleSmith beer. 120107

Bottle 750ml @ gunnfryd
Pours cloudy deep amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits, and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. with a long sweet fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

A really quality brew. Aged for about two years. Pours golden red and clear. A nice flavor to it with massive malty greatness. Really enjoyed the mouthfeel on it and it was nicely carbonated. Great brew.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2012 A - pours cloudy red/orange/brown with tan light head. 

S - Aromas of apples, doughy yeasts, bread, dark sour fruits and Belgian yeast. 

M - Nice medium body with no carb. Dry feel with nice warming ending. a little tart throughout

T - On the nose is apples and yeasts.  Dark sour fruits, cocoa,  and brown sugar. on the palate. Warming sour ending.

O - Overall good belgian strong dark. Interesting having the cocoa and dark fruit combination with the yeasts.

7-

750 mL bottle.  Pours a red-tinged amber with an off-white head.  Ripe red fruit aroma, green grape, caramel, mild yeasty tartness.  Flavor has red grape, caramel, molasses, and cocoa.  As it warms, it leans more heavily on the cocoa and grape, with an apply tang to it and a pleasant hint of oxidation.  Quite a nice one here, great flavors with a great balance.

bottle, 2007 i think. Notes of dried fruits, raisins, vanilla, ligh cinnamon, orange chocolate & tootsie rolls in aroma. Flavors of chocolate malts, dried dark fruits, light toffee. Very tasty & well done

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Smells of yeast and light fruits with some basement smells. Tastes of semi-tart red berries, caramel, and some yeast. Full bodied. Texture is syrupy. Medium carbonation. Finishes dry but tart.

75 cl bottle.
Pours hazy ruby red colour with small head. Aroma of bread, belgian yeast, dark ripe fruits, caramel, toffee, plum and some spices. Flavour of sweet caramel, ripe fruits, spices, belgian yeast, light malts, some berries and wood notes. Strong carbonation. Quite refined brew with rich and smooth palate.
5436

75 cl bottle @ home, no BBE info
Sweet aroma is somewhat perfume-like and has some semi-dark fruits typical to aged belgian ales. Flavour is oaky and somewhat sweet with cherry notes. Somewhat wine-like feeling here. Nice.

750 ml bottle.
Pours a dark amber colour with a thick white head. Aroma of rich dark fruits, spices and some yeast. Flavour of rich dark fruits, caramel malts, vanilla, yeast, spices and plums. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, warming, fruity finish. Alcohol warms nicely and this is pretty much a wine-like Belgian strong ale.
Vintage Unknown.  A succulent rich beer that reminds me of great Belgian beers.  Slightly sweet up front but dry with good length in the back palate.  This is a beer to savour with rich flavours.0

2006 bottle given by Peter Zien during Rbsg 2008 visit to Alesmith, thanks Peter! Have been aging this one awhile. Pours somewhat of a murky brown with no head. Brown sugar, pear, wood and light alcohol in the nose. Flavor has notes of apple, raisin, brown sugar, woodiness, light alcohol, some Belgian yeast fruitiness and ends with an awesome vanilla twinge. Carbonation is very light with a medium body.

Cloudy orange/amber pour with quickly dissapating tan head. Aroma of caramel and molasses and fruity overtones. Nice carbonation wit taste of caramel, toffee, spices and molasses. The aftertaste is whats hurting this beers rating as it had a definate salty bitterness (wierd).

Ok, but not great. Poured with a nice light tan, foamy, frothy, head that lasts a long time and a little lace. Color is a cloudy amber brown. Aroma is solvents, malt, caramel, yeast. Flavors much like nose, with sweetness standing out but a little confusing to me as it matches sweet solvents. Body and carbonation are ok. Finish is like flavor, of average length and no hint of booze.
Smooth, not an overly strong aftertaste and als very delicate.  Nice palette and dark cherry tones.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 8 Oct 2011) Reddish amber colour with brief, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with caramel, dried fruit and a slight acidity. Malty, fruity taste with notes of dried fruit, oak wood, vanilla, caramel and a slightly vinous, tart finish with hints of yeast. Almost full body, fairly sweet with a gentle spicy bitterness. A bit different, but tasty and very nice.

GABF 2011.  Slightly hazy rusty gold, very big off beige head. Aroma is belgianesque with a lot of yeast and funky light fruits, some toffee, and some mild spice. Mouthfeel is very bubbly. Flavor initially has a lot of bubblegum, but then dark fruit yeast, sweet toffee, and a little alcohol esters. Overall a little too sweet and imbalanced.

750ml bottle w Erica at Stifflers. Dark red pour w light red hue and medium off-white head. Dry, dark fruits like prunes and some grape flavor. Almost like a kriek. Very little aftertaste. Sweet but somewhat balanced. Drinkable, but does not hide the alcohol well at all.

Bottle at CBC, London, thanks to Warren. Pours hazy, dark ruby with a sturdy, creamy white head. Aroma hold caramel, Belgian yeast and candi, some leafy and herbal hops. Very sweet flavor, caramel and toffee, toasted candi and malts, light herbs. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Fairly warming finish, lots of sweetness, brown and toasty sugar, caramel and toffee, slight herbal bitters, rich cake, mild yeast. Excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours a light brown color with a slightly mocha head. Aroma is typical belgian yeast. notes of dark candy and dried fruits are strong. taste is very yeasty. Lots of sweet sugars give way to some more alcohol and vanilla finish. Would love to have another to age. and i managed to rate a beer at my own wedding

Cremig malzig-hefiger Antrunk mit gelungener alkoholischer Würze. Das Bier wird im Mittelteil malzlastiger, was die Hefe aber nicht davon abhält, vergorene Fruchtnoten in den Vordergrund zu bringen. Geringe Herbe, hohe Karbonisierung. Süßlich, harmonisch, voll. Zudem etwas salzig. Süßmalziger Ausklang. Vollmundiges gelungenes Bier. 11/12/12/13/12/12
Bottle at home in Skövde. Amber with a beige small head. Sweet malty aroma. Sweet licorice flavor.

Gewürziger, lieblicher, weißweinsäuerlicher Geruch. Süß-gewürziger Auftakt. Mitte dann schwerer fließend, ölig, zitronig, gewürzig. Malzsüßer, rosinig-gewürzter Abgang mit angenehm alkoholischem Flair.
Beachtlich.
4/5 in darkness. Smells sweet malty. With a sweet malty taste and a similar finish.
75 cl bottle, thanks to ekstedt. Golden beer, offwhite head. Fruity malty aroma with spicy notes and some citrus. Malty, fruity, spicy flavor.

Ive been hanging onto this for 1.5 years now I cant wait any longer I need to drink it. Bottle opened with a gush!! Crap did this go bad on me? Clear root beer brown with a tall cap the lingered for a long while. Aroma reminds me of Unibroue Maudite, dark apple, sweet malts, yeast, wood, hints of red wine, and noticeable alcohol. Good strong flavor, candy sugar, roasted malt, hints of banana but not, yeast, nice spice, lots of wood, and weak coffee. You can taste the non flavoured alcohol that warms the stomach..yes I can taste the non flavoured alcohol, prove me wrong I dare you. The more I drink this the more I like it but this may be because Im getting drunk. Entire bottle now empty and getting hard to watch the girl who kicked the hornets nest subtitles are getting blurry, wife keeps telling me to stop pausing so I can read whats happening. Anyway beer was good but dont think it lived up to its legendary status, drink a Unibroue Maudite and youll be getting the same thing.

Bottle. Courtesy of ekstedt. Pours clear red copper  with a great beige head leaving lace. Aroma is sour, dry, sweetish, fruity and vinous. Flavor is vinous, pungeant, fruity and sourish. Finishes sour bitter
Bottle (75 cl) from the Cracked Kettle. Caramelly aroma with dried fruits, and some alcohol. Meidum bodied, soft carbonation. Swemi sweet, bitter alcoholic finish.

(Bottled, rated 2011-07-07) Hazy dark reddish brown with a medium head. Strong aroma of ripe and dried fruit, sweet maltiness, warming alcohol. Flavor is lightly alcoholic, with sweet and ripe fruit, sourish red wine - even vinegar. Surprisingly thin and carbonated, although the malt sweetness makes it at least medium-bodied. A somewhat strange mix of vinegar, alcohol, and sweet malt. Probably needs to age a few years to balance the mixture.

OK, I think I kinda like this one. Dark copper with a lasting creamy topper. Clove, pepper and brown sugar lead the stampede of aroma out of the glass. Rich fruit greets my tastebuds; shake hands with plum, raison and some slightly overcooked english toffee. A note of sherry plays in the background. Chewy, long and complex finish. Glorious.

(Bottle) Pours hazy brown with dark amber highlights. Sand coloured head. The aroma holds yeast, candi sugar, pears, grapes, apples, other fruits,  almond past, subtle hops and earthy spices. Solid malt base and nice yeast character. The flavor is medium sweet, light bitter and light to medium acidic. Tones of citrus, spices, sugar, malt and subtle hops. The mouthfeel is tart and round with near medium carbonation. Citrus and spicy finish with some almond paste. Medium to full bodied.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of daknole. Thanks Dak! Gusher. Dark brown appearance with a big tan, foamy head. Dark candy sugar, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, Belgian yeast, light fruity aroma. Slightly fruity, dark chocolate and candy sugar, vanilla, Belgian yeast, smooth dark malty flavor. Alcohol is hidden well, though there is some warming on the finish. Quite nice dark Belgian ale.

On tap @ the brewery.
Orangish brown brew with a small amount of off-white head.  Aromas of Belgian yeast, dark fruit, booze, and vanilla.  Chocolatey flavor with caramel, vanilla, toasted marshmellow.  Decadent and complex - like liquid desert.

Huge thanks to daysinthewake for getting this bottle out my way. Long-time want. Served in a Russian River "TION" goblet.

Pours a dark brown with a nice bright hue in the light. Creamy off-white head with some good lacing on the way down. The nose is complex with plenty of Belgian yeast and a good dosing of dark fruits. The flavor doesnt hit quite as hard and isnt as complex, though I think it would really benefit from a bit of aging. Medium body and quite creamy without any noticeable alcohol. Really well done.

At AleSmith tasting room. Reddish brown. Fine head in plastic tasting cup. Deep aroma of bread and yeast. Belgian dark ale done to style well. Sweet with little hop presence. Dry finish keeps it refreshing. Nicely done.

Bottle. Pours with a creamy and creamed-colored head on a tawny dark murky copper brown.  Vanilla, dark fruits, some candy sugar, toffee, malty and fruity sweet.  Citrus, toffee, dark sweet maltiness, very fruity yeastiness, slight bitter-sweet chocolate.  Medium body thats slightly chalky and decent carbonation.  Warming and nice.

Poured out a deep crimson brown, really fantastic foam, sticky lacing .. . aroma of fruit, pie, brandy and brown sugar soaked rum .. . medium mouth .. . overall a well made beer but needs a bit for thickness .. . Inflammable means flammable? What a country.

Tasted on 8/18/11 from a 750mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours clear dark red with an average beige head that slowly recedes to a bit of thin lace and a decent collar.  The nose is fairly sweet with caramel malt, some red berry fruits, spicy Belgian yeast, and a bit of acetone alcoholic heat.  The flavor is nicely balanced with a good amount of caramel malt, spicy yeast, and red berry fruit.  The body is medium and somewhat oily with average carbonation and a long caramel malt, spicy Belgian yeast, and berry fruit finish.
bottle shared at 5k tasting - got some age, oxidation with raisins and plums, yeasty bread and toffee malts. Nice belgian spiciness, a touch sour and warming boozey finish.

Pour is amber with a nice frothy white head. Aroma is quite malty with a fruity background  - watermelon, banana - alcohol also.  Taste is a nice sweet bread malt, belgian yeast.  Nice beer for the style.

medium brown with large white head.  nose of dark fruit and belgian esters.  low bitterness before strong esters with more dark fuit prior to a nice warmth and complexity with tempered fusels.  a wonderful belgian dark strong

(bottle from Sparky, thanks Eric!)  Pours dark reddish-brown with a light tan head that recedes quickly but leaves good lacing when swirled.  Aroma of mulling spices, Concord grape juice, Cold Duck sparkling wine, and strawberries.  Takes on a caramel edge with bananas as it warms further.  Even further warming adds in the booze, and once this addition occurs, the Cold Duck and Concord grape scents morph into red wine territory.  Flavors of grape soda, strawberry, light raisin, sugary plums, with caramel and faint chocolate on the finish.  Cherries show up in abundance with further warming, and provide a slight tartness.  A bit of bread in the far finish too which lends some dryness to a  very sweet fore, providing a good counterbalance.  Some alcohol warmth.  Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is lively.  Overall this is an excellent Belgian Strong, and I definitely need to acquire another bottle of this quality concoction.  I dont think Ive ever had a bad beer from this brewery.  Thanks again Eric!

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2014 Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured a very hazy dark brown color with an enormous foamy orange-beige head that lingered forever and left a bit of lacing. The aroma was cherry, Dr Pepper, bread and rosemary. The flavor was tart and tangy Dr Pepper, sourdough bread, rosemary, anise and pepper with a strong boozy presence. The finish was long, tangy and herbal with lingering cherry. Fairly full bodied. Well done.

(Bottle,  0.75l, at Pikkulintu, 20110708) The beer poured reddish brown and a little bit hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had fruitiness, malts, spices and hops. Palate was medium bodied, warming and quite dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, Belgian style yeastiness, vanilla, sweetness, aniseed, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity, malty and sweet. A really nice Belgian style beer.

750ml bottle shared @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours brownish red with a medium head. Very strong aroma of malts, spices and alcohol. Taste is quite strong and complex as well, with notes of malts, spices and caramel. Sour and sweet, quite raw. Long lasting, warming finish. Alcohol burns through, but its well balanced. Tasty, very complex and balanced Belgian style ale. Couldve used a bit more aging, though.

750 ml. bottle poured to sampler glasses at a local tasting party,with a brownish copper color, modest, off white head foam and a fair amount of spotty lacing. The aroma was a touch of yeast tartness, mid-fruit, some syrupy sweetness, and hints of vanilla and caramel.  The flavor had more of a sour nature, with some finishing, dry, vinous character, nicely suddued alcohol warmth, and effervescent carbonation, in a medium body. Tasty!

Yeasty aroma with fruits and some vanilla poking though, some banana as well.  Flavor is a blend of fruits, yeast and vanilla, and other sweet yet subtle flavors.  Nicely bodied, alcohol twist to it, quite carbonated.

Aroma: yeast, coconut, dark fruit, alcohol, boozy, acidic.
Appearance: light ruby colour, off-white head.
Flavour: acidic, sweet, prunes, wheat, dark fruit, roasted malts, ash.
Mouthfeel: lively
Total: interesting.

Deep red pour, small white head. Aroma has strawberry, pepper, yeast, caramel, berries, dough, figs and raisins. Also some vanilla and crisp chocolate. Taste has similar stuff, yeast, vanilla, chocolate and caramel. Quite big on the palate, lots of oak and alcohol to spice it up.

08 vintage pours murky brownish red with very little head. Smells of strong belgain spices, dark fruit, raisins, prunes and some earthiness. Dark fruit, belgian candied sugars, toffee are most notable in the taste. Mouthfeel is medium to thick and finish is sweet dried dark fruit.

Pours amber with a small white head. Aroma has berries, belgian yeast, caramel, figs and raisins, hint of chocolate. Taste has berries, candy, figs, yeast, raisins, caramel, nice balancing bitterness, dry finish. High carbonation helps it avoid becoming cloying.

Pours amber/ruby with off white head. Aroma is caramel, belgian yeast, sour berries, raisin and some bready notes. Taste is ripe plums, sourness, alcohol, grapes and the raisiny caramelish belgian sweetness.

The aroma is champagne and cherries. Dark Belgian spices; grapes and raisins. White wine? Its a bit musty.

The appearance is deep red-orange. Decent head, lasts a few minutes. Good color, deep and cloudy.

The flavor is musty malts, yeast and funky Belgian flavors. Really nice and dry; more champagne. Fruits and that dry yeast.

The palate is thick, fizzy, dry, creamy. Dry and perfect for style. Belgian dubbel vibe; akin to a cherry ale (if thats a thing?).

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 750mL bottle, pours dark orangey amber with a large off-white head. Aroma of yeast, candied sugar and light caramel - less dense than what is to follow. Flavour is rich, dense and complex - candied sugar upfront with lots of yeast, with bubblegum and subtle caramel - perfect amount of sweetness. Huge carbonation. Excellent brew.
750ml bottle shared by jsprime with kish84, jb84, and myself. pours burgundy with a lasting head and lacing. nice dark fruit nose. grapey. slight sour, slightly metalic. very nice brew.

Pour mahogany with a nice beige head great lace. Aroma grape juice, raisins, dark fruits, chocolate, candy sugar, yeast. Taste more dark fruit, raisins, a touch metallic, Belgian yeast, candy sugar. MF pretty full body mild carb. Pretty good Belgian but Ive had better. Thanks JSPrime for share :D

750 mL bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a Trappist glass. Pours hazy reddish with a moderate tan head. The head remains and leaves a small amount of lace. The nose has big notes of molasses and a hint of grapes, along with a touch of clove and pepper. The flavour is moderately sweet with flavours carried through from the aroma. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and minimal texture. Overall, an excellent Belgian style ale with ample complexity and a nice aroma. Worth another try. 2011-04-09

Bottle from Ørsted; 10% ABVMahogany color, dark, with small sized creamy head. Nice aroma of caramel, mature, with a light scent of dark fruits, vanilla and wood. Bold structure; strong caramel and malt flavor, quite sweet, with a light fruitiness and some late liquorice; low bitterness; in the final the alcohol warmth is clearly perceived (maybe too much). Similar to many common Strong Ales from Belgium, nothing spectacular, but a solid brew indeed.

750ml bottle from Julios. Bought in December 2009. br />
Appearance : Clar amber with a small brown head. Long head retention.

Aroma : Nice belgian yeast with notes of red fruits. quyite nutty. A bit floral.

Taste : Light floral hops with belgian yeast and light dry fruits. Quite nutty.

Overall : Nice stuff but I expected a bit more. Nice dryness with great nutty notes. Interesting floral hops. Gets a bit better with time. Very well made. Rather well balance and elegant.

Bottle from Whole Foods Tribeca. It pours a clear dark red-brown colour with a large foamy white head. The nose is very, very fruity: date, plum, cherry, raisin, cranberry, wood and a little spearmint. The taste is dried cranberry and cherry, raspberry, date, prune, plum and towards the end there is some caramel, vanilla and a little chocolate. The alcohol is well hidden, which makes for an easy drinking and very well balanced strong ale. Wow Alesmith make top quality beer!

The beer pours medium brown with tons of carbonation. The head rises a good 4 fingers of light tan head, decently creamy. The retention is nice lasting several minutes. The lacing is very nice as well.

The aroma is medium, smells must like any other belgian dark ale, light hops, some carmel.

The taste is ok light malts on the front, some alcohol on the back.

The feel is a little light for my liking, but drinkable.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Arms Vasagatan, Stockholm. Ruby red colour, beige head. Aroma is raisins, plum, some sweet malts, mild yeast as well as some slight alcohol. Flavour is plum, loads of hops, some alcohol as well as mild yeastyness. Fruity and yeasty finish.

Bottle; Pour is Clear amber with an off white head - this brew retains well. Lacing is negligible.  Aroma is Belgian, but there is also some dark fruit and chocolate, as well. Ill admit it - this brew was underwhelming out of the gate. Dark fruits, candied sugars, a nice belgian yeast strain, with a slight alcoholic note here. Ah - and a touch of vanilla? There is a slight vinousness to this brew , finishing on the dry side. A nice brew -

Bottle, pours a brown clear body with a tall just barely off white head. The nose is fully of toasted caramel with some chocolate and dusty notes. The flavors start out very yeasty with some banana notes, but as it warms the slightly burnt caramel flavors really come out. Some dark chocolate notes, and a tough of herbs, coriander maybe, also poke out. This finishes very dry, much like champagne, with a nice hop bitterness that melds with the chocolate notes just perfectly.

750ml bottle. So maybe I dont just get this beer but apart from nice peat smell the taste, aroma and everything else just dont do it for me. Gave it a chance to breath and warm up but still not that great. Hoping that maybe it just needs to age but the peat and yeast just doesnt do it for me.
Bottle.  All kinds of cola and cheap whiskey flavors.  My first disappointment from AleSmith...

750mL bottle.  Pours a reddish-brown with large, fizzy, off-white head.  Little head retention and no lacing.  Nice yeasty aroma with dark fruits.  Taste is similar to the aroma with some sweetness; grapes.  Warm from the booze but doesnt really feel like youre drinking 10.6%.  Dry, abrupt finish; the beer is strong up front but leaves you hanging at the end.  Good, but not worth the money.
Alesmith is always a favorite.  Slightly brown pour.  Nice belgian profile.  I have another one aging for next year.
Copying score from old notes, do not rember flavor enough to write a description

cuivre, qcq bulles.
Malt et chocolat, levure belge et sucre candi qui ressort bien.
En bouche, levure, caramel et malt allant de suite vers un style plus belge avec un peu de chocolat en retrait ainsi que du sucre candi.

2006  Bottle - 500th Rating - have been sitting on this on for a looong time. Flat and syrupy but an intense earthyness comes out instead of a cloying sweetness.  Starts like a barleywine  but ends very unique.  The hops have broken down and the bitterness has mellowed to almost nothing.  Strong and almost savory flavors plus dark chocolate come out.  The sweetness threatens to be oversweet and cloying but ends up with a fantastic balance instead.  Not sure what this tastes like fresh, but five years made it very impressive.
A really easy-drinking champagne-like Belgian from AleSmith. What a coup it was picking this up when we visited the brewery in November. Love this one!

Thanks to SeaBass for this one.

A: Pours a muddy brown hue with a very small head.

S: Sweet caramel, brown sugar, toffee, and mild dark fruits.

T: Very sweet yet tasty. All the candy sugars are there with brown sugar and toffee standing out. Mild tones of chocolate, caramel, and sweet summer fruits.

M: Fuller in body, rich, smooth, and sweet.
Thanks to cbkschubert.  Dark reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Very carbonated. Aroma is light fruit, yeast. Taste is fruity, yeasty, very tasty. Little dry aftertaste.

2009 bottle, opened for new years, who says it needs to be the weak stuff during the bowl game watching, this was a dark brown almost black with a hint of red around the edges. just as youd expect, dark fruit and woody flavor with a hoppy finish that is really just tremendous.

Clear brownish golden color with bubbly white head. Aroma belgian yeast strain, spices, cloves. Taste is very sweet with an interesting mid taste almost like pungent garlic and fruity with under ripe pears.

I actually think the commercial description on this one is VERY accurate.

Shared bombed with jcos...  Doesnt taste much like any other beer Ive had....Id say its closest to a traditional belgian dubbel, but with more (noticeable) booze.  The yeast is extremely dominant at the nose and front of palate.  Its got a lot of carbonation as well, which I thought was kind of odd.

Our plan is to age the other one a while, see what flavors develop.  Its well crafted, for sure...but I wasnt quite sure what to make of it.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2012 75cl, at 10%Vol, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, slightly vinous, yet balanced, clear, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Cloudy brown appearance with a thick beige head. Aroma is of spice, chocolate, caramel, light notes of prune, and lots of bready yeast. Taste is of caramel, chocolate, light leather, dark fruits, toast, and candy sugar.

Pours a cranberry rust color with aroma of citrus and alcohol.  Taste of alcohol and bitter mild sourness.  Throughout the beer you can taste the mixture of the ingredients.  More like a wine than a beer.

Pours muddy brown with a dense head.  The aroma is wonderfully complex with tart fruit like cherries, sweet malts, and brown sugar.  Some coriander as well.  Lively mouthfeel.  Sweet and tart fruits, earth, chocolate, dark raisins, hops in the finish, candied sugars, and a sweet rich finish.

bottle at Morries tasting(12Nov10)pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is sweet toffee, vanilla and pepper.  Flavor is caramel malts and sour orange with lots of yeast character lingering in a lengthy finish of booze and esters.  I love it.

Pours a cloudy brownish-red with a large off-white head. Aroma of yeast, caramel, and alcohol. Flavor of chocolate, caramel, fruit, and quite a bit of alcohol. Very smooth all the way through with surprisingly abundant flavors even with the high alcohol content.  A very good beer.

Aroma has hints of sweet malts, alcohol, and a little bit of fruit. No head when poured into my snifter. No lacing. Brown/orange color, hazy/cloudy. Taste is somewhat sweet, malty, boozy,  with hints of dried fruit.

Bottle @ Toronado, San Francisco, shared with Muhunthan before jumping on the big metal bird home. Slightly murky reddish brown pour with a minimal off white head. Fairly vinous aroma which comprised sweet malts, dark/berry fruits, chocolate, spices and yeast. Flavour started out pretty sweet and displayed similar qualities to the nose. Full bodied and slightly sticky mouthfeel. Booze factor was pretty brazen and led to a warming finish. It was a toss up between this and the speedway stout, and whilst this is a pretty good beer it wasnt quite the taste and sensual sensation I was hoping for to send me on my way home. Im sad to say Im regretting my choice a wee bit now ! Big thanks to all the cool people we met in Cali who helped proceedings go with more of a swing, a bit of local knowledge goes a long way!....we all had a blast, cheers !

Bottle. Amber body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is caramel, spices, alcohol. Flavor is caramel, yeast sweet warming alcohol. High carbonation. Watery texture. Maybe I had to high expectations to this one. In my opinion a bit dissapointing.
Smells of deliciousness. Pours a dark orange brown color with an off white head. Smellsof old molasses and sour brown sugar. Taste is of souring raisons and cooked brown sugar. Pretty tasty.

Poured a hazy brown, with an offwhite head.  Aroma of grapes and raisins.  Some caramel and sour yeast notes.  Taste is sweet with raisins and brown sugar.  Overall it is slightly sweet with mild sourness.  Overall very good.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable but not too bad.
Amber with a small white head. Aroma of malt, bread, dried fruit and alcohol. Sweet malty flavour with lots of dried fruit, alcohol and spice. Rather cloying sweetness

Tap at Alesmith. Would swear this was belgian if blind tasting, but with that awesome craft from Alesmith. A little vinious. Its dry, spicy and luxurious. I am usually not a huge fan of highly phenolic belgian beers, but this is excellent.

750 from Jungle Jims. Pours a hazy copper with over a finger of frothy white head. Nose of yeast, prune, hints of cocoa. Spicy belgian ale. Fruity and spicy with a fair amount of booze. Should let one of these cellar and mellow. A mild amount of tart, recognizably belgian. I like this, but liked the xmas mikkeller better.
Im not normally so into the Belgian styles, but this strong ale was quite good.  Tons of flavors.
Poured a lovely mahogany color with a tight white head. Strong, aggressive aroma of yeast, citrus and malt. Taste was surprisingly subdued, given the aroma, but complex, malty and well balanced.

[3468-20101113] 1pt9.4floz bottle. Rich roasted fruits and licorice aroma. Clear (bottom is hazy and full of floaties though!), dark amber body with a quick foam off-white head. Full body is fairly boozy. Tasty!
Overheard: "Get the spoon out for the bottom."
(Vintage 2007; c/o HogTownHarry, w/ him, blankboy, jerc, tupalev)
Bottle at ÖBWF 2010. It poured a hazy mahogony-amber-ruby liquid with a small white head. A nice beer with a fruity and malty flavour.

Fruity and full up front; but mellow and golden in the back.  It packs a punch but you wouldnt know it until you start slurring your words and your mother in law busts you.  Vanilla, cherry, raisins and a slosh of faint alcohol coats the back of the throat as it warms your dingleberries.  Reminds me a little of Chimay Bleu, which is no mean feat.  Good stuff!

Bottle. Pours a clear and copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and spices. The flavor is malt, some acidity, spices and alcohol. The palate has some alcoholwarmth and sweetness. Overall a beer just above average.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Pours an amber/brown with decent head and nice lacing.  Smells of fruit, vanilla, brown sugar.  Tastes of toffee, dried fruit and brown sugar.  Very very sweet.  Lots of alcohol on this one too.

Medium beige head. Hazy brown body with lively carbonation. Light malty spicy aroma with milky dried fruit notes. Dry-sweet milky honeyish alcohol taste with herbal cinnamon and wine grape notes. Hot mouthfeel. Fullish body. Dryish wine grape, pepper and cinnamon aftertaste wiht oily herbal notes. Nice, but mildly disharmonic. Could also hide the alcohol better. (0.75l bottle, Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

Aroma: humle malt gær citron Ud.:rubinrød klar  Skum:hvidt  E.smag:sød moderat bitter moderat  Krop:medium For.:olie Brus:blød 
f 75cl døe 27/10-10

Bottle:  Beautiful amber color with a very short lived beige head.  Smells intoxicating with sweetness...  caramel, toffee, dark fruits, vanilla.  Really, I could bury my nose in this forever.  Flavor is rich with toasted malts, dark fruits, caramel, and the yeast is spot on.  Nothing wild going on here, just a good solid BSA.
Pours dark amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, fruit and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, burning alcohol, raisin and pepper. Medium bitter. To much alcohol for my taste.

0.75L corked bottled brought home from Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg.  A solid shiny blond head atop a near-clear, orangey hued, nut brown body.  Inviting Belgo-yeast aroma.  Bubblegum and perfume,  fresh yellow fruits and a floral note. Also a whiff of biscuits and caramel. Strong malt body. Gently sweet and caramelly with choco tones. A fine berry-ish fruitiness, too. Mild spices underneath. Medium to full body. Nice effervescence, almost like a fine champagne. Pleasant warming finish. Complex and rounded.  A treat.

Maltbolcher, Sherry, vinøs.
Rødlig, klar, perlende med tæt skum.
Bitter og meget sød.
Tør, livlig og cremet.

(750ml bottle) cloudy medium brown-orange with a nice lasting creamy ring of bubbles. Nose of vanilla, raisins, alcohol, mild funk/woody aromas from the Belgian yeast, and sweet rum. Taste of milk chocolate, raisins, Belgian yeast, vanilla, alcohol, rum, nice sweet caramel to balance it all out. Complex and delicious. Body is medium to thin, creamy and lots of dark fruit flavors (mostly raisin and dates) linger for a long time. This is excellent.
caramel, pretty strong alcohol, but its sweet.  pretty great smell, and i would rate this higher on taste if it wasnt for the burn going down.

Bottle shared by OleR.
Soft mouth feel, very compex. Redcurrants, balsamic vinegar, very Belgian yeast profile. Fruity.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, sweet malt, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums, & dates), raisons, caramel, and some spice; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very good brew.

9-10-10  750ml bouteille: Brune, trouble, avec une mousse abondante et une très légère effervescence. Aômes prononcés de cassonade, avec des notes aigrelette dhoublon et de céréales. Elle apporte des saveurs de cassonade, de malt caramel, avec une solide touche dhoublon. Mince en bouche, elle apporte une asser grande amertume en finale.

Bottle. Low creamy and lasting white head. Clear dark brown body. Alcohol dominated malt choccolate vineous aroma. Spicy vineous choccolate flavor with a hint of vanilla. Long aftertaste. Low carbonation. Well balanced without being too dominated by the high alcohol percentage.

Hazy copper with reddish brown hues, thick two-finger tan head with wonderful lacing. A perfect-looking beer. Aromas of dark ripe fruit, spices, black cherries, with bready malt and yeast in the background. Sweet dark fruit and warming alcohol are felt first on the tongue, then rich caramel malts, spices and a hint of yeast. Candy sugar and mild citrus peel as well. Sinful creamy smoothness on the palate, lively carbonation, and very pleasant residual fruit sweetness. The alcohol warmth enhances every facet of this. Outstanding.

Fløska, huge thanks to Pinball. Hazy deep dark amber colour. Sweet quite pleasant dark fruity spiced aroma, yum yum! Good filling mouthfeel indeed. Very pleasant flavour, sweet with dark fruits, spices and chocolate, plenty of caramel. Sweet long lasting caramel dark fruity spiced finish. Great brew!

Bottle shared by MrPickes...thanks Andy! - Pours rosy amber with a small off-white foamy head. Lots of Belgian yeast on the nose, with sweet candi sugar, and tropical fruit, most noticeably passion fruit. Taste is very similar, with a bit more roast and a ton of fruit on the finish. Solid, but not remarkable.

Bottle from kmweaver and  shared at a local tasting.  Thanks again Ken.
I think the only issue with this beer is that I had it after the number 1 beer from the night and a total surprise.  I think I may have ratted it higher id I had this one first, but it did not measure up to the Roots.  Cant say anything bad about this one and I am glad that I just found myself another bottle on a trip I went on.  Cant wait to try this again.

cloudy red brown, smooth but also fluffy offwhite head
nice belgian aroma, nice dry and pretty tight. lightly spiced, and  it works without getting too spiced.
flavor is dry, boozy, faint fruit peel, faint yellow fruits.

Bottle. The beer pours hazy brown with a big creamy off white head. The aroma is yeasty spicy with notes of loads of caramel, cardemom, cinnamon, dark fruit and light hops. Wow heavy ripe fruit, light acid, spices, light toasted caramel and chocolate. Very complex and delicious!

750 mL bottle from South Bay.  Brownish orange pour with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of apples, pears, grapes and Belgian yeast.  The flavor is completely unexpected given the aroma; big woody and bourbon notes dominate the palate yet the alcohol is subtle.  There is a bit of fruit detected in the flavor but far less than what the aroma would have you believe.  While the alcohol is understated in the flavor you do feel its warmth.  Given the complexity and gravity of this beer it is surprisingly drinkable and not too heavy.  Yet another outstanding beer from AleSmith (not that I expect anything but the best from them at this point).

A: The pour is a slightly cloudy amber color with a very thin off-white head, sort of khaki color.

S: Plenty of sweet caramel and brown sugar and perhaps even more sweet, dark fruits. Some plums, figs, dates, and cherries, but a fair amount of alcohol as well.

T: A great toffee and brown sugar component along with some caramel. This provides a nice sweet, malty base and the dark fruit flavors just sort of sit on top. Somehow, the alcohol is a bit more pronounced than on the nose.

M: The body is medium with a really quite smooth carbonation.

D: I would have enjoyed this quite a bit more were it not for the obvious alcohol presence. This might be a good one to age and allow to mellow.

A lot of pressure for No. 400.  I was going to go with something more low key but Leafs93 set me straight.  Pours a deep red color with an off-white foam head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit and caramel.  Sweet start with notes of caramel.  Nice medium mouthfeel.  Excellent brew.
Pours hazy brown.  Aroma is yeast, grass and apple/pear.  Taste is sweet with a crisp finish.  Very smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2014 "Wow! after hearing this beer ages very well (but not having the patience to wait) I was prepared for a bit of a letdown. Soooooo not the case. Wonderful beer in every aspect. Upon opening the bottle, my nose was met with a frikkin symphony of complex aroma...fruit and spice, but not like I expected. More chocolate undertones, plum, sweet candy. Neither the flavor or aroma was overly yeasty. The beer itself was a little darker than your average grand cru, but then again, there was nothing average about this one. BIG complex flavors of more plums and candy sugar, toffee, brown sugar, etc, etc. Lots going on, but it was still so pleasant to drink. The 10% abv drinks easy because its so smooth, but its a big bodied beer as well. Another GREAT from Alesmith. oooh...forgot about the licorice too...too many good things to list in there! 2010-like Speedway, not nearly as good the following year. last year 4.8, this year 4.2. WTF?! 4.5 average. Is Alesmith slipping?"

Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with James. Pours a deep, dusty hazelnut brown with a full, foamy, rich beige head. Trailing, sludgy lacing. Aroma of baking bread, warm biscuits, cinnamon, dark, ripe fruits, and traces of banana and clove. Full bodied with a relatively boozy, sharp, yet somehow rounded and fairly well-balanced mouthfeel. Finishes quite abruptly, especially for a Belgian strong. Very good brew.

Got this at the Raven Cafe in Prescott AZ, but enjoyed it in my Living room in Metro Detroit! My wife(MereLikesBeer) and I had this for our one month wedding anniversary, and it was lovely! All the hype that I had heard about this brewery was true. The pour was dark, and had the aroma of dried plums and raisins. The flavor followed suit, paired with an incredible mouthfeel. Wonderful stuff, its too bad I cant get them here! 
Cheers!

Delightful. From a 750 ml bottle pours a clear amber with a big head that fades to a creamy covering. The aroma is malty with a true beer like scent that imparts to days of yore. The flavor has a nice lightness to it at first but then gives over to a slightly tart and tangy feel. The finish is quite dry. Great stuff.

Bottle. Red-brown, white head. Surly butter and a small berry sourness in the aroma. The taste is fruity, malty, buttery and spicy. In some ways this one reminds me of  "glögg". The texture has got the typical Alesmith smoothness.
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy and yeasty aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate. Disapointing.
750 ml bottle shared with Gotta and Jason.  Ruby red color, small brown head.  Aroma of homebrew esters.  Taste is very nutty, sweet and sour.  Great body, nice character.

Celebrating # 5300. 75cl bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours dark brown with a creamy lasting white head and lacings. Complex nose and flavor. Dark fruit such as plum and raisins. Brown sugar , caramel and hints of vanilla and oak. A bit of alcohol warmth. Full bodied. Lively carbonat Pleasant slightly tart fruityness. This is a huge beer!

Bottle.
This is a big spicy beer with some grape notes but I somehow find it to simple.
Bottle at Unibaren. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark browb. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, hops and syrop. Well balanced.
Bottle. Brown/amber with medium lasting light tan head. Flavour is malt, fruit, caramel, bitter and light.

750ml bottle via trade with phaleslu, thanks Peter! Pours a lightly hazed, deep amber colored body with a ruby tint. Finger-width, frothy and fizzy, tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is moderately malty with a nice, fruity yeastiness and creamy vanilla. Dried fruits, vinous, earthy pepper, caramel, some distinct alcohol, chocolate, toffee, pears, prunes, bananas, and a hint of toast. Flavor is similar. Pretty malty with lots of caramel, toffee, and a light chocolate for a medium sweetness with an underlying creamy vanilla. An up front alcohol that doesnt distract from the rest of the flavors and remains well hidden. More toast, vinous dark fruits, yeasty pepper and earth, prunes, raisins, pears, bitter orange peel, and a light Belgian candi. Finishes dry with a light bitterness and a lengthy, creamy vanilla, chocolate, caramel aftertaste with a pleasant mix of spice and fruit. Medium, smooth body with a medium-high, creamy, lively carbonation. Overall, a really nice beer. Lots of caramel, vanilla, and chocolate malts with plenty of fruit and yeasty spices. A pleasant, somewhat subtle Belgian character and toast add to the complexity. This is very well done and hides the alcohol well.

Bottle. Dark maroon in color, off white colored head, and clear.  The smell is dried fruits, yeast, more fruits, sweet, caramel, and sweet. The taste is lots of fruits, yeast, sweet, caramel, and good. Some alcohol, tang, and medium feel.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 Very nice, sweet aroma, a hot summer day in the country aroma, with a touch of yeasty funk.  Very sweet and rich, with dashes of smoke, yeast, and peaty hops.  Lots of brown sugary malt flavor.  Definitely a dessert beer.  Rerated upward in 2012.  Big, foamy pour and note the nice Alesmith bottle too.  Perhaps this batch had a different mix because it was not nearly as sweet - this time it was much more like a mainstream abbey ale - more yeasty and robust, and I liked it more.

Pours a  dark reddish brown with a thick off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, dark sweet fruits, and some chocolate. Flavor begins tart cherry and yeasty and then moves to a caramel sweetness. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Slightly sticky. Overall very good.

Bottle shared by boamr at the CDC release. Poured a thin clear orange/brown with a small off white head. Aroma is breast with notes of honey, raisins and anise biscotti. Thin bubbly body that finishes dry. Flavor of anise, bread crusts, honey combs, cardboard and caramel.
Bottle possibly past its prime. Pours a dark rust color with an off white head. aroma is vanilla, flavor is caramel vanilla and chocolate. much different than the first time ive had it.

Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. Only alesmith beer i have ever hated. just too big and bold with rasin and esters and fruit and phenols. had almost a rotten fruit taste. did not care for it.

10-JUL-2010, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Lovely brown with huge head.
Typical belgian strong, with loads of fruit (and dried fruit), charamel, and chocolate. Almost desert wine like but with a high carbonation and low alcohol (!) level.
Very fine and balanced brew.

Bottle. Pours a hazy deep amber brown with a light brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has notes of vanilla, sweet fruits and some floral notes with a slight light chocolate undertone. Flavor has sweet fruits, floral,l caramel and vanilla with a bit of chocolate building towards the finish.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 270610.
Amber with white head. Aroma of fruit and malt. Flavor with some yeast esters, dry.
Bottle. Orange like pour with tan head. Pear, toffee, chewy fruity malt notes with some light sweetness with hints of vanilla, caramel and chocolate  and a bit of warming through the fruit character.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a big tan head and tons of lacing. Flavor of caramel, dark fruit, nuts, and sugary sweetness. This is a really great, balanced beer, great for a 300th rating.

750mL from SouthBay, Pours a clear, deep red ruby with a towering yellow head that has absolutely insane retention and good to decent lacing. Holy beep. Nose at first is a sharp citric tartness, green apples, rich buttery caramel, mulled spice, mulled apple cider with whipped cream. Taste begins tart, dry, moves to caramel, spice, never moving to that characteristic sickly sweetness and old candy that plagues these dark fruit-forward Belgian strongs. But it does go a little papery, thin, cardboardy. Pretty yummy.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this beer. This is my 1,700th beer and it didnt disappoint.

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a white head. The aroma is sweet sugar with some vanilla and cherry notes. The flavor is cherry, caramel malt, brown sugar, alcohol, Belgian yeast and Belgian candi-sugar. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great American-made Belgian-style beer. Glad I got to try this one.

Dark brown amber pour off white creamy head .... aroma of vanilla, chocolate and belgian yeast ..... taste of dark fruits, vanilla and caramel malts .... very smooth and drinkable for 10% medium bodied ..... finishes warm and dry .... loved it

(bottle 750 ml) Dark ruby color with a thin dirty white head. Lots of sweet caramel malt notes at the start of the aroma with some very light yeast and fruit hints underneath. Flavor is sweet and fruity at the start with some very light and subtle yeast and spice hints near the middle. Finishes with a caramel covered apple taste and just the lightest hint of spice. Not bad, but a little too sweet.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, with cookie for the malt, cooked orange for the hops, earth for the yeast, and brown sugar, rum, date and alcohol in the background. Head is small, fizzy, off-white with fair lacing and good legs, and is mostly diminishing. Color is slightly hazy light copper. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic. Palate is medium to full, oily with a fizzy carbonation and a moderately alcoholic finish. This is one mouth filling Belgian Strong  Ale, and aside from sound it pleases every sense.
