(2003 Vintage) Pours a clear dark ruby with a minimal tan head. It clings to the glass not in typical beer fashion as lacing, but rather it exhibits legs like a big Cabernet. The aroma is sweet, caramel, and fruity. The flavor is also sweet caramel with some nutty/woody flavors developing mid-taste. The flavors mix and mingle in the mouth and keep exposing new dimensions of depth. The roasted malt flavor is the most surprising. The body is medium-full, almost creamy. The alcohol is hidden; the only noticeable effect is a slight numbness in the mouth. Overall an excellent Belgian style ale. This one should really cellar well and I will need to revisit it in a year or so. Yum.

Dark brown color. Mead head. Aroma is malt, brown sugar, hops, clove and banana and I could spend a long time just smell this beer. A full-bodied Belgian Strong Ale. Malts are fruity (bananas, peaches and raisins) bready and sweet. Very well balanced. Extremely smooth, nearly creamy taste. Touches of must and wood, vanilla and caramel. Some sherry and wine like characters are here as well. The 10% alcohol is very well hidden. Flavors of figs and plums come out as it warms, and I swear it get even smoother tasting. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Dark brown color with ruby edging through light. Almost no head or lacing. Aroma is full of candi-sugar and spicy light noble hops with some corriander. When this warms up, lots of grape & fig notes come through as well. The flavor is lightly sweet initially and burns on the way down, but a very refined malty/bready body and hop end. Well balanced, lots of alcohol. This is a straight forward, well made belgian. Not much complexities, but still well made.

Very nice hazy mahogany pour with almost no head, and what was there left quickly. Looks to be a bit of spotty lacing.  Big bread aroma, sourdough, then some malt and some fruit. Seems like it is maybe grape, some banana. There is some spices lingering around. Caramel comes out a bit in the flavors. More spices. Some clove. Fruits again, more banana.  Very creamy, but crisp. Thick body with a bit of an alcohol bite finishing it off. Definately warms you up a bit. Very nice Belgian though. Thanks goes out to Eyedrinkale for this beauty.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 75 cl. Vintage 2000. Thanks Secret Santa cquiroga! Nice copper color with only a smallish light tan head and small lines of lace. Initial aromas of blueberries and fruit, but as it warms the malt kicks in. Aromas of caramel, toffee and hint of alcohol. First sip reveals a smooth and refined brew. As this warms the flavors just keep coming. Light malt sweetness starts with rich flavors continuing throughout the quaff. Light bittersweet chocolate mixed with a cream caramel. Some maple and vanilla flavor later on. Has hint of cask-wood , and gives the impression of a cask pour. Very nice refined brew. I shall enjoy the late few oz. watching the highlights of the Packer victory. today.  Eagles beware!

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 1/2/04.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, bought at A & J Liquor in Covina, CA 12/22/03.  2000 Vintage.  My first beer of the New Year, and I wanted to make it a special one.  This beer pours a dark resinous amber brown, mostly transparent body, with little head left in it.  Not much real lacing either, but the tiny outline on the edges of the glass struggles mightily to make lovely patterns of carbonation bubbles as you tilt the glass back and forth.  Even without much going on, it still looks pretty damn stately in the glass, and the body looks very full, lending a maple syrup appearance to the whole thing.  The aroma is fantastic-- a little bit of buttery sourness and fruit (certainly recalling the cidery, citrusy elements of other Belgian ales), resin, some rich caramel like an aged barley wine, and some drying vinous notes to go along with the subtle hints of dark unsweetened chocolate.  Delightful.  Initial taste reveals wonderfully (but unsurprisingly) full mouthfeel, silky smooth texture with a directness and crispness to everything that makes it all feel so carefully crafted and controlled.  The flavors are not that prominent immediately, so it requires a little concentration to pick out whats going on.  If you sit and savor the beer, though, its fantastic in its simplicity.  Only a hint of sourness, and then lightly toasted yeast, tingly malt like a doppelbock, an undercurrent of alcohol warmth, and some raisin.  I still get a little bit of the unsweetened chocolate, but its mostly disappeared behind the caramel and yeast.  Alternately dry and mouth-wateringly rich finish, with mostly a tangy resinous and raisiny trace, and the toastiness is lovely.  Reminds me of the aged Hair of the Dog Golden Rose and especially the aged Fred that I had a few months ago.  Very elegant, very delicious stuff.
GABF '03 Deep copper in color,clear.aroma of ginger,malt,other spices.Flavor of rasins/dates and caramel.Very nicely done.

(750ml bottle) Pours a deep red body and headless. Malt, cherry and spice nose. Nice alcohol balance in the flavour, along with raisin, brown sugar, roasted malt and spice. Nice oily texture, spice and alcohol finish. What's all the hype about?

Psychprof was generous to let me sample his 2000 that he had been saving at the summer gathering.  I was blown away by this beer.  The commercial description states that it's "like a fine wine" and I can see that comparision. this had to have been one of the smoothest beers I've ever had.  It had a light amber/yellowish appearance.  I could detect the aroma of apples, lemon  and cinammon and almost like a warm apple cider kind of feeling to it.  The taste was creamy and amazingly smooth with a sweet light finish. If ambrosia was bottled this would be the stuff.  Thanks again to pyschprof for sharing this delicacy with me.
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 A sweet, well rounded ale with tastes of chocolate and prunes/raisins/dates. Light bitter warm finish.

2003: This brew pours with a beautiful red brown/burgundy body topped by a thin fizzy head with little lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet and malty with spicy notes, plum accents and a slight roastiness.  The flavor is slightly sweet and malty with notes of plums, a touch of spice and a slight yeastiness.  The finish is sweet yet bitter with a slight roastiness.  Full bodied and slightly dry with a touch of warmth.

Drak mahogany color, well carbonated but quickly dissipating foam. I was surprised that there was no cork in the bottle. Dark fruity, fruitcake and caramel aroma combined wth mint and clove spice. Baked ginger and fruitcake flavor, brown sugar and caramel. Spicy dryness, orange peel and slight bitterness in the finish. Interesting complexity, a fine beer to sip and savor.

Has some of the same rich aromas of the great abts.  Rich malt and spices, plums, just a hint of alcohol.  Appearance is nice, but unexpected.  Brew pours dark, reddish brown.  Flavor is rich with flavors of raisins, more dried fruit, and a bit of spice.  There is definitely an alcohol kick in the finish.  Yummy and complex, approaching greatness.

(gabf'03)  No need to type anything into the comments field - just read the description of this ale.  But I'll still give it my own personal stamp.  Sweet, fruity flavor of raison, caramel and bubblegum accompanied by spicy undercurrents of ginger and nutmeg.  If you can find this, cherish it.  Tuck it into bed at night and read it stories so it grows up to be big and strong.

2003 Vintage. Dark and hazy plum colored with no head at all. Aroma is really malty with some fruit like dried cherries and figs. I don't get the vanilla/chocolate aroma, maybe that was a different vintage. Mouth feel is a bit weak with some dryness and lacks the excitement of a Belgian Grand Cru. Flavor is malty sweet with a hint of caramel and cocoa. Alcohol is very present in aroma and flavor. A bit dissapointing.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: 2003 Vintage:  Hazy caramel/ruby color with zero head, no lacing.  Aroma is mainly alcohol with some strange fruity sweetness, almost artificial smell.  Flavor is  very sweet with some woody notes.  Alcohol is prelevant but overpowering.  Dry and short finish.  Definetly not my favorite Alesmith brew.

2003 Batch (75 cL bottle):Dark ruby amber in colour with a very thin tan head. Smells of sweet caramel, chocolate, figs and pit fruit - VERY nice! Medium-bodied; High carbonation, very sweet flavour of dark pit fruits with strong malt characteristics. Aftertaste sweet and bitter. Very pleasant all the way around! Overall, a very good beer...could use some age though! I was lucky enough to get this 75 cL bottle in a recent trade with Rodolito (thanks Dave!) and got to share it with Haddon90 (Phil) in Knoxville, Tennessee on 28-September-2003.

Clear and dark, deep brown with reddish hues and a frothy, off-white head. Roasted aroma, sharpish alcohol edge and a thick, molasses-like sweetness. Very warming and pleasant to drink. Kind of like Horny Devil's bigger, wiser brother.
Dark amber.  Sweet nose of flawers and peaches.  Highly carbonated.  Peaches, vanilla, and banana strong flavors throughout.  Wonderful.
Pours a deep copper/amber color with hardly any head. Nice aroma of fruit and malt. Tastes smooth with a hint of alcohol on your tongue. A must have! Thanks jgb9348 for bringing this to Knoxville!
Indian clay color with virtually no head.  Commercial description is accurate.  Interesting flavoring and a nice mouthfeel.  Alcohol is very noticable.

Vintage 2000,Cloudy orange-amber color,nice medium sized head that with a decent amount of lasting power.Nice sweet aroma of fruit and mild malt,dried fruit possibly raisin,very mild hint of alcoholwith a mild spiciness following up in the rear.The flavor is mildly fruity,nicely spiced,medium alcohol and a few other flavors dance on the palate that are hard for me to pick out but quite good.This is a very sweet brew all around,the after taste is great with a decent alcohol burn going down.A very well worth it trade,I just wish i had a few more for later sampling.Thanks go out to captain Cougar for this brew.With out him i would be drinking Swill tonite.

Vintage 2000. Today was my lucky day. I'm always looking around for this fine ale. As I peruse the familiar isles of Harvest Ranch Market, I notice something strange- '00 bottles of Old Numbskull. I thought, they haven't had this for over a year. As I move on aside, there she was, '00 Grand Cru. Even at the 00 price of 9.99. Anyhow, it has aged gracefully. Slightly passed it's prime but still  legendary. Nicely conditioned with lingering head. Clear, deep color. Alcohol dominates the aroma, but plenty of fruit .. raison, plum.
Flavor profile isn't quite the same, slighty less complex than a year ago but deeper nonetheless. Some tartness developing, but to style. And the best part, warm numbing sensation as the finest beer ever brewed in San Diego goes down!
2002 vintage -- Redish copper color and a nose that reminded me of apple cider.  Almost anise spiciness.  Great balance of malty sweetness with pungent bitterness.

Nose similar to the Horny Devil with pockets fulls of spice. Caramelly malts are rich and thick but yeild to a buttery, vanilla, eggy sweetness that I don't care much for. Seems artificial and sticky with out of place milky coffee creamers (the flavored variety) that joyfully get knocked the hell out by the swift, burning, heavily spiced alcohol. Strange.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2004 Brewtopia 2004:  Same score, well -0.1, I would say that this was hazy, not cloudy. RateBeer Summer 2003:  2000 vintage:  Cloudy orange color, bready/cake, gingerbread, molasses, plum, vanilla, aroma with a bit of spice.  Very smooth for the ABV, ends sweet.  A masterpiece.  I want a full bottle
Huge spicy coriander aroma.  Spicy flavor is quite bold.   Alcohol presence is quite noticeable.

This ale has a cloudy, burnt orange hue (covered by a cloud of meringue foam) and a yeasty, caramelly aroma that reminded me of....candied yams!  It's very smooth, and VERY sweet.  Perhaps too sweet, even for me.  Have it with (or for) dessert - perhaps the Sauternes of beer?

2000 vintage.  I love the first line of the commercial description -- "really needs to be tasted to be truly appreciated" -- unlike all those other beers that one can appreciate without tasting.  Fruity, spicy aroma, some lemon frosting, orange, cinnamon, apple and faint alcohol.  Reddish-copper color, head forming just a slight ring.  Flavor is sugary, lightly alcoholic and estery, with notes of butterscotch, toffee, vanilla and spice.  Very still and smooth with a fruity finish.  Interesting beer.

(2000 @RBSG2003):  Clear copper body with minimal off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, raisin, light alcohol.  Taste is sweet, fruity, raisin, orange, finishing with nice alcohol warming/light burn.  Medium palate.
Caramel colored body with moderate off white head. Has a big sweet aroma. Flavor of vanilla and finishes sweet. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2005 This brew pours a small head of finely sized bubbles that leave a fair lacing and it has a transparent dark amber body.  It also had a strong alcohol aroma.  Initially, the alcohol flavor comes through, but later softens in the finish.
7/4/7/4/14

Rerate:
Large light brown foamy fine mostly diminishing head.  Transparent copper dark ruby red brown body with a fair lacing.  Vinous caramel malt aroma.  Tingly smooth initial very strong tingly vinbous malty biting finish.  Very yummy strong vinous caramel malt rasiin port like flavor.
7/4/9/5/18

UPDATED: APR 6, 2004 2003 Vintage sampled on 4/6/2004:  Pours a murky dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is very bready and full of caramely Belgian malts with a nice balance of yeastiness.  Good sweetness and flavor throughout, but still could use some mellowing to reach its full potential.

2000 Vintage sampled on 5/20/2003: Pours a cloudy dark copper with a thin lacing head.  Aroma is a complex mixture of soy, brown sugar, and port.  The light syrupy palate leads into a smooth, semi-sweet and robust body with a medium bitterness.  Belgian malt and a touch of candi sugar are prevalent. Very well rounded, and a great American Belgian beer.

Very, very smooth brew, and one of the best palates I've tasted from a Belgian strong.  Caramel, vanilla and a silky maltiness.  Very subtle and wonderful to drink.  Celebrated this at a graduation party.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 (2-3 year old, 2000 bottle): At the summit of a massive vanilla tower, a velvety caramel wine pool undulates and emits a creamy alcohol bouquet to soften voraciousness...Prodigious chocolate grapevines hug berry-scented candelabras...An object of comfort and romance...

(Quite fresh 2003 bottle) : Creamy alcohol perfume emanating from stately chocolate-coated fruit and vanilla...Similar flavor profile but much more mature and reverend than Maîtresse du Moine...

(1 and half year-old 2003 bottle) : Aging beautifully, no important change and exactly the same points once again. Its excellent, no doubt about it.

A more recent batch had obvious raisins and cherries atop the roasty touches and caressing alcohol; still a marvelous sipper, perhaps a little too clean/filtered for my tastes in the style, but at this level of quality, I certainly dont mind.

I hear its passed its prime, wow, I loved to have it in its prime.  Cloudy, carmel colored(not served proper?), small head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast.  Slight bite up front, malty,caramel flavor.  Vanilla comes thru, but maybe I've had too many Imperial Stouts, I can't say the Chocolate come thru.  Some sweetness on the finish, nice brew!

2000 edition. I have a feeling this bottle may have aged a bit differently than others. Color was copper with an orange hue and a huge white head. The aroma was sweet, faintly malty and dominated by chocolate and orange. Complex flavor dominated by chocolate and orange. Just like an orange flavored chocolate bar. Behind these flavors were sweetness, plum and sherry notes, and a light spiciness in the aftertaste. The alcohol was also a bit noticeable in the aftertaste, but not overpowering. Full mouthfeel, light carbonation, and a little syrupy. I wish I had more bottles like this to go with dessert after a wonderful meal.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 2006 bottle. Virtually no head. Body is hazy dark amber, unfiltered. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), with notes of sherry/cardboard and alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Not much to like here...as is often the case with Alesmith bottles, virtually no hiss and little carbonation. Oxidized aroma, another Alesmith hallmark. Sad.

2000:Pour leaves oarnge/brown beer with a tan head. Big,cherry aroma,with some sweet/toasty,malt and spice. Mouthfeel is creamy and soft. Flavors are also caramel and cherry,with some spice leading to a bready,fruity finish.Not very complex but very tasty.Thanks buddy!

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 This beer rocks!... The aroma holds heavy notes of rich malt, caramel and plums. Lesser notes of alcohol, red wine, tawny port, cinnamon, clove and vanilla. This ale has a crystal clear, copper hue. Very small, fizzy, khaki colored head. Quickly and fully diminishing. The flavor is wonderfully malty with bursts of caramel, brown sugar, tawny port, dark fruits and warm alcohol up front. Well balanced with a perky hop presence and acetic notes along with more wonderfully warm alcohol on the backside. As well balanced as this Belgian ale may be, the malt and candy sugar win out by just a hair. Medium/full bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Medium length, very lightly tart, acetic, dry finish. Another great offering from Alesmith!
A solid brew that the iceman and I polished off.  It was pricey but damn was it worth it!  It wasnt too complex but it was smooth and clean.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2003 Updated for the 2003 Vintage (Hoppage): Crystal Clear reddish brown with an aroma of Toffee & honey, it's smooth on the palate & a delight to enjoy
brownish/red, malty, w/ overtones of sweetness. very well balanced. A truly wonderful brew. thx spacemonkey

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2003 This one was truly great. Alesmith has once again done themselves proud. Damn near expensive, but was truly worth it. A great blend of flavors for a enlightening taste. The cool thing with this is that if you smell the beer,you'd swear it was some type of fuel cause it had a really powerful alcohol fume thing going on. Solid.

2000 edition: 7/28/02 ..aroma was of cherry syrup, sour and lambic-like but sweet and very inviting...color glowed a red loveliness with a thin halod off-white head...WOW...creamy carmel toast with burnt cherries...alcohol...alcoholic cherry ice cream...tingling... Very Cherry with creamy notes and very alcoholic I must say, again...seems to age quite well..I still have another I will age for a few years more..
Re-Rate 8/23/03: Still have 1 more in the cellar..this time all that and soggy cardboard in the aroma..a little chocolate showed up as well as the other flavors mentioned..I also did not notice too much alcohol at all this time..

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Pours a dark brown amber hue with a nice thick tan head.  Aromas of dark fruits, a little nutty and sweet.  Flavors of the same with prunes in the front with vanilla, toffee and a hint of cocoa.

Poured the color of a rind of smoked cheese.Aroma is very similar to the better belgians. Alcohol is nowhere to be found in the nose.This has the complexity of a belgian but is so smooth and mellow.Damn! How does AleSmith do this? This to me is very comparable to a Rochefort 10 but with a lot more drinkability. Very glad I saved this for my 100th.One addendum, the only hard part is finishing 750ml. of this at the end of a night. This stuff puts an ass whooping on you.
Outstanding belgian style beer.  crisp, sour, rich, spicy, sweet...hard to define but easy to drink

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2009 8/6/02  2000 Vintage: Slight aroma of brandy. Smooth, mellow, rich carmel start and a creamy wine like finish. Warms the tummy as well as the palate. Very well done AleSmith !!!    Well miss you Skip.
9/25/03 2003 Vintage: Dark burgundy brown color with just a wisp of head. Nose is sweet with a hint of alcohol. Start is smooth, sweet, rich and complex. The finish is lightly hoppy and the aftertaste is wine like. By GOD its like a Belgium Barley Wine. Thanks Peter.

the first thing i notice about the aroma is the alcohol.  but along with the alcohol comes a bit of hop spiciness accompalied by rich malt scents.  the flavor does not dissapoint, very complex.  I dont know where to start.  the first taste is a little sweet but the flavor gets richer as it goes through your mouth and develops into very full flavor and then tapers into a light sourness reminiscent of wine.  you need to try this one to believe it.

Deep copper/red. Thin white head, sticky lace. Nose of perfumy yeast,winey alcohol,caramel,vanilla, and others. Creamy as hell in mouth. Starts off with a hearty dose of mellow yeast,faint hints of chocolate,caramel, cottoncandy, and malt mixing in with the winey alcohol. Medium bodied and just enough carbonation. Warming,soft,mellow and a sweetnesss (vanilla-like?)that is heaven. aLso has a bit of yeasty/oaky sourness as well. This is killer complex stuff, I cant really find much wrong with it. This and the old numbskull from these guys were outstanding, cant wait to try all their stuff. Thank you PsychProf!
Great. Very mellow, like Immort Ale, and a little less agressive than that one. The candy sugar is just noticeable deep down in the aroma. A great beer.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: While it may be doubtful that I can match the sheer verbosity of my fellow raters with regards to this beer, I shall give it the old college try.  Slightly hazy, red colour; huge malt aroma; flavour of sweet peaches, plums, toffee, with a vibrant fruitiness and a big, deep malt.  In five years, this will go Gales POA on you. Again, this was a Gusler special.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2005 2000 bottling:  Very alcoholic aroma with some Belgian yeast, apple, vanilla and wood?  Little carbo with loads of crystal malt and semi-sticky head.  Finish is vinously sour.  I also noticed some appley texture in the middle.  This is the definition of a diverse and complex beer.  Problem is, how will I ever get through this huge bottle sober?  Oh well, I know it will be worth it.  Bottle conditioned with a capped cork under the cap that must be removed with a cork opener.  My face is on fire, oh wait, that is just the alcohol slapping me silly.  This is a world class ale from a very small, hard to find brewery.  Only if it was available elsewhere than S. Cal.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2003 If I would have known it was going to take me more than a year to restock this magnificent beer, I would have never drunk my last bottle. From what I can ascertain from the local package store is that there seems to be a labeling problem that is delaying its shipment to Arizona, and Im mad a hell and Im not going to take it anymore, guess I will just order a case via the internet and be damned the expense.

The pour a deep lucent brown with ruby highlights, the head behemothic in size, spumescent in texture and a winsome light tan color, the lace a velum like sheet to conceal the glass. The nose has a deep malt walnut like sweet aroma, rich and full, fresh a treat for the eye, nose and palate. Start is creamy rich and sweet, top is moderate to full in feel and the finish spiny in its acidity, vinous, hop spicy and desert bone dry aftertaste, a real Hoot in my books.
